And the proposal for module defer is that you can like I guess like if you're thinking about performance on a website, maybe we'll step back a bit. There's a couple things you can do to make your your app more performant, right? You can not download all of the uh JavaScript that is needed until you actually need it. That's like lazy loading, right? And you can dynamically require in JavaScript. But the the other part of JavaScript is not just loading or downloading the actual JavaScript. It's it's actually executing it. It's the browser needs to parse out the entire JavaScript so that it understands what the methods are and everything. And if there's any code that needs to be run right away when that thing is is required then or imported, then that will run. And that execution takes up CPU, and it can make your app slower. So we have immediate importing and immediate execution. That's just a regular import. We have lazy loading, which is a dynamic import. Um, and now we are going to get it at a stage 2.7, which is deferring the import, meaning that it will download it right away, but it will not execute it until you call or until you use that code inside of there. But uh there's many other types of data in JavaScript that can be looped over, right? You can loop over objects with a for of. You can loop over strings and get every single character. Uh Maps and Sets can be looped over. Node lists are, if you query selector or something, that's not an array, that's a node list. Um, and then probably the biggest one is like generators. If you have a generator function, you can loop over those, and every single time that you loop, you get the next item from the generator. So, iterables can also be asynchronous, meaning that you can await inside of them.
